ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Numbers of species
ygData.msgSnippet: Well, for what it is worth, my version of NEAT did in fact CLAMP the species.  As you may recall, I specifically did not allow more than X species to exist.

Well, for what it is worth, my version of NEAT did in fact CLAMP the
specie=
s.  As you may recall, I specifically did not allow more than X
species to =
exist.  And as I recall, I treated each unique topology as
a distinct speci=
es (very low compatibility threshold).

On 9/8/05, Derek James <djames@gmai=
l.com> wrote:
> On 9/7/05, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
=
> >
> > I'm actually not completely sure what the word "clamp" means. Does
=
> > it mean you are doing dynamic thresholding in the style of my NEAT
> > =
system, or does it mean you literally stop speciation from
> > progressing =
after some number already exist?  (I guess Derek or you
> > may be able to =
answer this question) My dynamic thresholding is
> > constantly moving towa=
rds a target number by moving the
> > compatibility threshold, which doesn'=
t seem like a "clamp" exactly,
> > so I think clamping may be a third optio=
n.
> 
> Okay, not sure "clamped" is a good word either, or that I even
> un=
derstood exactly what Ken's code was doing.
> 
> I remember early on when w=
e were working on our implementation, and
> were specifically working on so=
me of the visualization tools, I saw
> the speciation graphic in Ken's 2002=
 paper, and it looked like for a
> population of 150 there were something l=
ike 8 species.  We hadn't
> really tuned our compability threshold so we we=
re getting way more
> species than this.
> 
> I thought that in an email ex=
change Ken said that he set a maximum
> number of species (this is what I w=
as referring to as "clamping" the
> number of species).  It sounds though, =
in this discussion, that it
> actually works by restricting the maximum num=
ber of members each
> species can have, which would in practice would very =
much the same way
> I would guess.
> 
> It's interesting that you brought t=
his up.  We're going to be looking
> a lot more closely at our population d=
ynamics in the coming months.
> We've had discussions on this list about ki=
lling off stagnating
> species in order to add more dynamism to the search =
algorithm.  That
> is something else we currently haven't implemented.  So =
we'd like to
> take a closer look at what's going there, but yeah, these is=
sues are
> still pretty hazy.
> 
> Derek
